holidays.name: National Dessert Day
holidays.description: A sweet celebration encouraging everyone to indulge in their favorite desserts, from cakes to pies and everything sugary in between.
holidays.origin: While its exact origin is unclear, National Dessert Day has become a popular unofficial food holiday embraced by dessert lovers worldwide.
holidays.funFact: On National Dessert Day, many bakeries and restaurants offer special deals or even free bites of dessert to celebrate the sweet tooth spirit!

holidays.name: Be Bald and Be Free Day
holidays.description: An empowering holiday celebrating baldness in all its forms, encouraging people to rock their bald heads with pride and confidence.
holidays.origin: Created to promote self-love and challenge beauty standards, this day reminds us that bald is beautiful.
holidays.funFact: Some communities host fun Bald Walks or shaving parties to celebrate this day together, showing off their shiny scalps!

holidays.name: National Mole Day
holidays.description: A quirky celebration by chemistry enthusiasts marking Avogadro's number (6.022 x 10^23), a fundamental constant in chemistry.
holidays.origin: Established in 1981 by American chemists to foster interest in chemistry and honor the mole concept at 6:02 a.m. on October 23, but some extend festivities starting October 14 to build excitement.
holidays.funFact: Mole Day is often celebrated with mole-themed puns, experiments, and even mole-shaped treats to make chemistry fun!

holidays.name: National Yorkshire Pudding Day
holidays.description: A delicious day dedicated to enjoying the classic British side dish, Yorkshire pudding, typically served with roast beef and gravy.
holidays.origin: Though an unofficial food holiday, it celebrates a traditional British staple dating back to the 1700s.
